awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Predictive Multiscale Modeling of the Mechanical Properties of Polymers 3D Printed Using Fused Filament Fabrication
awd_abstract_narration:
This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer Our Future (DMREF) grant will provide new scientific understanding of the Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) process and its effect on the underlying molecular structure and properties of 3D-printed polymers.  3D-printing is driving a paradigm shift in the design and manufacturing of objects both in every day life and in high-tech applications. The integration with computer-aided design allows printed parts to be customized quickly and inexpensively to meet unique specifications and provide new functionalities. FFF is the most widely used and fastest growing 3D process and FFF printers dominate the growing desktop 3D printing market, driven by the low cost and relative simplicity of the printer construction and wide availability of feedstock materials. Although widely used, applications of FFF printed materials are limited by modest strength and toughness and large variability in material properties. This award supports fundamental research to understand how the printing conditions affect the materials properties of polymers printed by FFF. This fundamental knowledge is needed to advance the application of FFF to structure-critical components, provide computational tools to accelerate the design of FFF printed parts, and develop the next generation 3D-printing technology for polymers.  Thus, the outcomes of this project will benefit the US economy.  This project will also provide opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to participate in multidisciplinary research that involves close interactions with national laboratories and product design researchers, and create innovative outreach actives for K-12 on the science and engineering of 3D-printing.  

The research objective of this project is to uncover the relationships between important printing parameters and feedstock material properties and the anisotropy, strength, and toughness of the printed material. We will develop an integrative research approach with iterative feedback between printing, modeling, and experiments at multiple length scales to investigate: 1) the molecular orientation of the extruded fiber, 2) the nonequilibrium structure and anisotropic, viscoplastic behavior of the annealed fiber, 3) the entanglement structure, strength and toughness of the fiber-fiber weld, 4) the anisotropic viscoplastic and damage behavior of the raster structure, and 5) the thermal history and residual stresses in the printed part. Finally, we will apply the experimentally-validated multi-scale modeling framework to design the properties of feedstock material and printing parameters to improve the strength and toughness of the printed part.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the DMREF program was to discover the relationships between the key materials processing parameters, such as the printing temperatures, printed line height, and line orientation, on the anisotropy, strength, and toughness of fused filament fabrication (FFF) printed materials. The main findings of the DMEF were as follows.  High shear stresses in the nozzle caused the polymer chains to disentangle and become highly aligned.  However, the molecular alignment did not affect the rate of chain diffusion across the weld.  The highly aligned chains retracted mainly along the direction of stretch rather than diffuse through the weld.  Molecular dynamics simulations showed that existing continuum models overestimated the degree of disentanglement flow under large shear rates, and a new slip-link model was developed for chain disentanglement based on the findings of molecular dynamics simulations.

            We developed a new peel test of a single printed filament to measure the Mode I fracture energy of the weld and performed tear tests to measure the Mode III fracture energy of a printed weld.  Both tear and peel tests showed that printing at higher temperatures increased the weld time and produced stronger welds.  However, the peel energy and tear energy also depended on the geometry of the printed filaments and tear specimens.  Finite element simulations showed that bulk plastic deformation in the printed filament can contribute significantly to the tear energy and peel energy depending on the height and cross-sectional area of the printed filaments.  The strain softening behavior the thermoplastic filament causes stick-slip crack propagation. However, bulk plastic dissipation can be minimized for thinner printed filaments and larger specimen height for tear tests. Finally, we develop a new method, the razor induced fracture test (RIFT), to measure the fracture energy of the weld more directly.  In RIFT, a sharp razor blade is cyclically driven between two printed filaments to induce incremental mode I crack propagation then retracted to measure the sliding friction between the razor blade and printed filament.  The fracture energy is measured from the steady-state force applied to the razor blade minus the friction force.  

            We measured the effect of printing conditions and environmental conditions on the structure and mechanical properties of a printed wall.  We found that increasing the environmental chamber temperature of the FFF printer decreased warping by decreasing the temperature gradient in the printed part.  Humidity (up to 0.15% by mass of water in the filaments) resulted in a high porosity (up to 12% porosity) in the printed filaments.  The high void content produced a more ductile and tougher behavior along the longitudinal direction but a more brittle behavior along the perpendicular direction of the printed filaments.  Finally, we performed finite element simulations of the uniaxial tension stress response of a printed wall in the longitudinal and transverse directions to investigate the stress distribution though the printed filaments.  Based on the findings, we proposed a method to calculate the effective transverse and longitudinal modulus for a given width, height, shape of the cross-sectional area of the printed filament, and the width of the bond.  

 

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Thao (Vicky) D Nguyen
por.por_txt_cntn:
The overarching goal of the DMREF program was to discover the relationships between the key materials processing parameters, such as the printing temperatures, printed line height, and line orientation, on the anisotropy, strength, and toughness of fused filament fabrication (FFF) printed materials. The main findings of the DMEF were as follows.  High shear stresses in the nozzle caused the polymer chains to disentangle and become highly aligned.  However, the molecular alignment did not affect the rate of chain diffusion across the weld.  The highly aligned chains retracted mainly along the direction of stretch rather than diffuse through the weld.  Molecular dynamics simulations showed that existing continuum models overestimated the degree of disentanglement flow under large shear rates, and a new slip-link model was developed for chain disentanglement based on the findings of molecular dynamics simulations.

            We developed a new peel test of a single printed filament to measure the Mode I fracture energy of the weld and performed tear tests to measure the Mode III fracture energy of a printed weld.  Both tear and peel tests showed that printing at higher temperatures increased the weld time and produced stronger welds.  However, the peel energy and tear energy also depended on the geometry of the printed filaments and tear specimens.  Finite element simulations showed that bulk plastic deformation in the printed filament can contribute significantly to the tear energy and peel energy depending on the height and cross-sectional area of the printed filaments.  The strain softening behavior the thermoplastic filament causes stick-slip crack propagation. However, bulk plastic dissipation can be minimized for thinner printed filaments and larger specimen height for tear tests. Finally, we develop a new method, the razor induced fracture test (RIFT), to measure the fracture energy of the weld more directly.  In RIFT, a sharp razor blade is cyclically driven between two printed filaments to induce incremental mode I crack propagation then retracted to measure the sliding friction between the razor blade and printed filament.  The fracture energy is measured from the steady-state force applied to the razor blade minus the friction force.  

            We measured the effect of printing conditions and environmental conditions on the structure and mechanical properties of a printed wall.  We found that increasing the environmental chamber temperature of the FFF printer decreased warping by decreasing the temperature gradient in the printed part.  Humidity (up to 0.15% by mass of water in the filaments) resulted in a high porosity (up to 12% porosity) in the printed filaments.  The high void content produced a more ductile and tougher behavior along the longitudinal direction but a more brittle behavior along the perpendicular direction of the printed filaments.  Finally, we performed finite element simulations of the uniaxial tension stress response of a printed wall in the longitudinal and transverse directions to investigate the stress distribution though the printed filaments.  Based on the findings, we proposed a method to calculate the effective transverse and longitudinal modulus for a given width, height, shape of the cross-sectional area of the printed filament, and the width of the bond.
